thread.title: New state study plots peak times for deer-vehicle collisions
thread.title_full: New state study plots peak times for deer-vehicle collisions | savannahnow.com

author: The Associated Press
title: New state study plots peak times for deer-vehicle collisions
text:
By The Associated Press MACON, Ga. — University of Georgia researchers have a new study out that could tell motorists the most likely times for collisions with deer in different parts of the state.
The research assessed available deer breeding information with reported accidents to calculate peak times that deer are on the move.
The Macon Telegraph reports that during rutting season, white-tailed deer search for mates and travel much more frequently.
James Stickles, the project’s lead researcher, said that depending on the location in Georgia, the peak rut may occur anywhere from October through December.
In Laurens County, Shane Dukes of Shane’s Body Shop in Dublin says he is already seeing an increase in customers whose vehicles have been in collisions with deer. The peak time for Laurens County is expected to be Nov. 3-9.
